title: Knowledge Representation
summary:
Knowledge representation takes various forms to capture and organize domain-specific information. Some common knowledge representation forms include:

Semantic Networks: These graph-based structures represent knowledge using nodes (entities) and edges (relationships) to illustrate semantic relationships between entities.It corresponds to Semantic Network-based Expert Systems.
Production Rules: They utilize a condition-action format, triggering actions when specific conditions are met, aiding in decision-making and inference within the system.They correspond to Rule-based Expert Systems.
Frames: Frames represent objects using structured attributes, providing a hierarchical description of an object's properties, relations, and behaviors.This corresponds to Frame-based Expert Systems.
Logic-based Approaches: These representations use mathematical logic, such as first-order logic or predicate logic, to express and reason about knowledge with precision.They correspond to Logic-based Expert Systems.
Ontologies: These formalized representations describe entity relationships and meanings in a domain, facilitating shared understanding across different systems or applications.They correspond to Ontology-based Expert Systems.

Each of these representation forms serves specific purposes and can be chosen based on the nature of the domain, problem-solving requirements, and the desired level of formalization and expressiveness.
